name: Chininum arsenicosum
Relationship: Compare: Chininum; also Ferrum Citricum (in nephritis with great anaemia; acid dyspepsia in chlorosis. Morbus maculosus Werlhoff); Chin in. mur. (in severe neuralgic pains around eyes, with chills; exaggerated sensitiveness to alcohol and tobacco; prostration and restlessness). Oenothera (effortless diarrhoea with nervous exhaustion; incipient hydrocephaloid). Macrozamia spiralis (extreme debility after illness; collapse).

Heart: Suffocative attacks, occurring in periodical paroxysms
Short of breath on ascending; cardiac dyspnoea; circulatory weakness after acute infections; early myocardial degeneration
Eyes: Intense photophobia and orbicular spasm; gushing hot tears
Stomach: Alternation of hyperacidity and decrease of acid
Thirst for water, yet it disturbs
Head: Tired feeling
Head feels too full
Throbbing
Great anxiety
Great irritability
Vertigo; worse looking up
Dull, heavy headache, frontal and occipital
Darting pains running up into head
Mouth: Tongue thickly furred; yellow, slimy coating
Extremities: COLDNESS OF HANDS AND FEET, KNEES AND LIMBS

details: The symptoms of general WEARINESS AND PROSTRATION produced by the drug have been utilized in prescribing it homeopathically as a general tonic, often with very marked beneficial and prompt effect. In diphtheria with great prostration, cases that are prolonged, especially, and in malarial affections, neuralgia, etc., it has been found curative. Asthmatic attacks which recur periodically, with great prostration. Icy skin. Pressure in the solar plexus, with tender spine back of it.
